Package com.rb.nonbiz.types

Class SignedFraction

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
com.rb.nonbiz.types.RBNumeric<T>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.PreciseValue<SignedFraction>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.SignedFraction
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<SignedFraction>
public class SignedFraction
extends PreciseValue<SignedFraction>
Similar to UnitFraction, but it's a general fraction that can have any value, including negative or values greater than 1.

Note that it is not necessarily in the set Q of rational fractions; see RationalUnitFraction for that, if you need one that's always between 0 and 1 (inclusive).

Unlike UnitFraction where the value must be in [0, 1], this is really just a BigDecimal wrapper.

You might wonder - why does this even have 'Fraction' in its name, when it can just be any number? We usually use this to describe numbers that are typically in the [0, 1] range, but can occasionally be outside that. For example, the cash portion of a portfolio is typically in [0, 1]. However, if we model $100 of a stock with beta of 1.8 as $180 US stocks + cash of -$80, then the modeled (not actual) cash portion can be negative.

See Also:
UnitFraction, Serialized Form
